   From: Nicole Barile Sent: Thursday, April 3, 2025 7:40 PM To: Chuck Adams Subject: Re: Larry and session postponements Hiya. I figured I'd email just you for now on this Larry mess 🙂. According to Andrea, Larry is not due any money for the Aflac sessions. She is correct, considering the language in the PA states he gets nothing for cancelations. That said, we would owe him  $475 for Aflac IF we had the old cancelation & postponement policy in the PAs. And we would owe Larry $1,400 for Group M  IF we had the old cancelation & postponement policy in the PAs. Grand total of $1,875.  I'm still unclear as to what, if anything, we are charging Aflac....but that's kind of besides the point. The facts are that Larry signed a PA (I believe multiple times) that had different terms. It would have been nice if he was alerted to those terms, but I don't think he was. And, his argument is that the new can/post policy (within 2 days & within 5 days) should not apply here. But that logic is flawed, because this new policy wasn't even in the PAs sent to him. It was brand new language that RP put in. She hasn't answered why - or maybe I missed that. Maybe she edited it because of Group M's unique canc/post policy....? Anyway, I know this is a headache, but here is what I'm thinking.... We pay him half of the total above - $937.50. We acknowledge the miscommunication - he should have been notified of this new language in the PA (was he??) We offer a gesture of goodwill & offer to pay 50% of what he would have received under the old policy What do you think? I will work on this process to make it easier going forward. Thank you! From: Andrea Wicks Bowles Sent: Wednesday, April 2, 2025 11:59 AM To: Nicole Barile Cc: Rebecca Parrilla ; Chuck Adams Subject: RE: Larry and session postponements   Hi Nicole, Thanks for figuring this out.  I am not ignoring you, just not really clear.  Aflac has done the following (to date): Sent me an email on 2/20 requesting to postpone three sessions: Culture and Communication 2/26 Inclusive Talent Review 3/06 Fostering Inclusion 3/12   Sent me an email on 3/21 requestion to postpone: LCI 4/10” Building Strong Virtual Relationships 4/29.   TODAY I spoke with Gina about the SOW postponement and cancelation language.  Aflac is scheduled an internal meeting on Monday (to discuss the future of the LCW sessions, and the contractual requirements).  Please note that in the Aflac SOW under cancelation, we say  “Scheduled sessions canceled within 15-30 days will incur a charge of 25% of the session cost, plus any nonrefundable travel expenses”   The language in the SOW does not mention what happens if sessions are canceled in advance of 30 days (but implies there is no fee).  I worry they may change (potential future) postponements into cancelations, for remaining sessions (or some of them such as Brave Conversations).       Larry’s  PA does not stipulate payment for either canceled or postponed sessions for the first batch of sessions (re: email Aflac 2/20).  And the PA concerning the email (Aflac 3/21) has Larry facilitating just the LCI.  In this PA, there is only cancellation language   “If any Project Deliverable with a specific date of performance is canceled or postponed: within 3-5 days of delivery, LCW will pay 50% of the agreed-upon rate for the scheduled session(s). within 2 days of delivery, LCW will pay 100% of the agreed-upon rate for the scheduled session(s).   This project assignment may be canceled at any time by Contractor or LCW. In case of cancellation, the Contractor will invoice LCW for the pro-rated amount due (based on working days, not calendar days), up to and including the last day of full-time work.”   Finally, we have invoiced and received 50% of the SOW fee.  AND we invoiced the Neurodiversity session that was delivered, and 100% of the PM fee.  They want to know if we are billing forward, or taking “from the prepayment pot”.  I need to meet with Chuck and SG  to answer this question before Thursday COB.  The complexity of this situation suggests a a live discussion.  Thinking about current and future implications goes beyond what we pay LB.   Cheers~   Andrea Wicks Bowles (She/Her/Hers) Senior Consultant LCW Website:

   From: Nicole Barile Sent: Tuesday, April 1, 2025 5:44 PM To: Rebecca Parrilla ; Andrea Wicks Bowles Cc: Chuck Adams Subject: Re: Larry and session postponements   Thank you all for your patience & RP for all your help! This was a confusing one 🙂.   According to my investigation 🙂, here are the Group M sessions that got canceled/postponed for Larry that would trigger any payment to him (using the old cancelation policy):   2/13 cancelation for 2/24 session = 11 days notice = 50% of $350 due to Larry — $175 due  2/13 cancelation for 2/28 session = 15 days notice = 25% of $350 due to Larry — $87.50 due 3/5 cancelation for 3/14 session = 8 days notice = 50% of $350 due to Larry — $175 due 3/17 cancelation for 3/21 session = 4 days notice = 75% of $350 due Larry — $262.50 due   Total due Larry (if we use our old cancelation policy language - which was NOT in his PA) is $700.   However, I do not know anything about the Spencer Stuart & Aflac programs. Were they cancelled? How much notice was Larry given? @Andrea Wicks Bowles: mailto:a.wicksbowles@lcwmail.com - Can you please answer this for me? It looks like maybe the Aflac sessions were canceled, but I don't know any details.   Here is the PA for reference.:

 Cancelations & Postponements language: Scheduled sessions may be canceled or postponed at any time before scheduled delivery at no cost, providing the session is rescheduled within six months, any non-refundable travel expenses will still be billed Scheduled sessions canceled or postponed within 8-14 days of delivery, if not rescheduled, will incur a charge of 50% of the session cost, plus any non-refundable travel expenses Scheduled sessions canceled or postponed within 3-7 days of delivery, if not rescheduled, will incur a charge of 75% of the session cost, plus any non-refundable travel expenses Scheduled sessions canceled or postponed within 2 days of delivery, if not rescheduled will incur a charge of the full program fee, plus any non-refundable travel expenses Cancellation and postponement charges will be invoiced immediately and may not be applied to future sessions Cancellation & postponement fees are in addition to the original session fees Scheduled sessions postponed more than twice, no matter the notice, will incur a charge of 50% of the session cost, plus any non-refundable travel expenses   One option would be to pay Larry an advance (50%?) for his future GroupM facilitations. I feel confident that the sessions will finally begin on Friday, May 2nd (I will try my best to get them to commit today during our meeting).  We can also guarantee him a certain # of sessions and also pay him a certain fee or pct (15%?) re: the sessions that were postponed. (Btw he emailed me that he wasn’t able to do April 28 after all so that date should be crossed off the list on the SOW and it’s actually a total of 16 GroupM sessions, not 18).I’m not sure there would have been a ton of prep for Larry for these sessions because he’s facilitated this content many times in advance, however, he did reserve the dates so in my opinion some courtesy compensation is warranted for the opportunity cost.  We had contracted to pay him $350 per GroupM session so that would be a total of $840 for 16 sessions.   Here’s the timeline of GroupM events in case helpful: 2/10/25: Emailed Larry first Project Assignment:

Nicole Begin forwarded message: From: Larry Baker Date: March 31, 2025 at 8:45:40 AM EDT To: Chuck Adams , Nicole Barile Cc: Rebecca Parrilla , Andrea Wicks Bowles Subject: FW: Email ﻿   Hello all,   I am writing to address the series of postponed training sessions with Group M and Aflac during February, March, and April, for which I have not received compensation despite significant preparation time. Detailed Session Breakdown Group M Sessions (9 total) 1.      Topic: Building an Inclusive Environment 2.      Scheduled Dates: 1.      February 24 2.      March 14, 24, 28, 31 3.      April 4, 11, 14, 25 1.      Contracted Rate: $350 per session 2.      Total Potential Earnings: $3,150 Aflac Postponed Sessions 1.      "How Culture Influences Communication Styles" 1.      Scheduled Date: February 26 2.      Session Rate: $300 1.      "Managing Bias in Talent Review" 1.      Scheduled Date: March 6 2.      Session Rate: $500 1.      "Fostering Inclusive Leadership" 1.      Scheduled Date: March 12 2.      Session Rate: $350 1.      Total Potential Aflac Earnings: $1,150 Total Uncompensated Earnings: $4,300 Compensation Proposal While recognizing the unprecedented challenges we are experiencing, I propose a fair resolution based on the following considerations: 1.      Substantial Preparation Time: Significant effort was invested in preparing for these sessions. 2.      SOW Flexibility: Existing contract language supports compensation considerations. 3.      Cancellation Policy Alignment: Proposing compensation at 50% of the original session rate. Proposed Compensation: $2,150 Negotiation Openness I am committed to maintaining a professional and collaborative relationship. I am open to discussing a mutually agreeable compensation arrangement that recognizes the time and expertise invested while supporting our continued business partnership. Next Steps I welcome the opportunity to discuss this matter further and find a resolution that works for both parties. Thank you for your careful consideration.

Hiya. I figured I'd email just you for now on this Larry mess 🙂. 
According to Andrea, Larry is not due any money for the Aflac sessions. She is correct, considering the language in the PA states he gets nothing for cancelations. 
That said, we would owe him 
 $475

Aflac
 
IF 
we had the old cancelation & postponement policy in the PAs. 
And we would owe Larry 
$1,400 
for 
Group M
  
IF 
we had the old cancelation & postponement policy in the PAs. 
Grand total of $1,875.
  
I'm still unclear as to what, if anything, we are charging Aflac....but that's kind of besides the point. 
The facts are that Larry signed a PA (I believe multiple times) that had different terms. It would have been nice if he was alerted to those terms, but I don't think he was. And, his argument is that the new can/post policy (within 2 days & within 5 days) should not apply here. But that logic is flawed, because this new policy wasn't even in the PAs sent to him. It was brand new language that RP put in. She hasn't answered why - or maybe I missed that. Maybe she edited it because of Group M's unique canc/post policy....? 
Anyway, I know this is a headache, but here is what I'm thinking.... 
We pay him half of the total above - $937.50.
 
We acknowledge the miscommunication - he should have been notified of this new language in the PA 
(was he??)
 
We offer a gesture of goodwill & offer to pay 50% of what he would have received under the old policy 
What do you think? 
I will work on this process to make it easier going forward. 
Thank you!

Hi Nicole, 
Thanks for figuring this out.  I am not ignoring you, just not really clear.  Aflac has done the following (to date): 
Sent me an email on 2/20 requesting to 
postpone
 
three sessions: 
Culture and Communication 2/26 
Inclusive Talent Review 3/06 
Fostering Inclusion 3/12 
  
Sent me an email on 3/21 requestion to 
postpone
: 
LCI 4/10” 
Building Strong Virtual Relationships 4/29. 
  
TODAY I spoke with Gina about the SOW postponement and cancelation language.  Aflac is scheduled an internal meeting on Monday (to discuss the future of the LCW sessions, and the contractual requirements).  
Please note that in the Aflac SOW under cancelation, we say  “
Scheduled sessions canceled within 15-30 days will incur a charge of 25% of the session cost, plus any nonrefundable travel expenses
” 
  
The language in the SOW does not mention what happens if sessions are canceled 
in advance of 30 days
 (but implies there is no fee).  I worry they may change (
potential future
) postponements into cancelations, for remaining sessions (or some of them such as 
Brave Conversations
).    
 
  
Larry’s  PA does not stipulate payment for either canceled or postponed sessions for the first batch of sessions (re: email Aflac 2/20).  And the PA concerning the email (Aflac 3/21) has Larry facilitating just the LCI.  In this PA, there is only cancellation language   
“If any Project Deliverable with a specific date of performance is canceled or postponed:
 
within 
3-5 days 
of delivery, LCW will pay 50% of the agreed-upon rate for the scheduled session(s). 
within 
2 days 
of delivery, LCW will pay 100% of the agreed-upon rate for the scheduled session(s). 
  
This project assignment may be canceled at any time by Contractor or LCW. In case of cancellation, the Contractor will invoice LCW for the pro-rated amount due (based on working days, not calendar days), up to and including the last day of full-time work.” 
  
Finally, we have invoiced and received 50% of the SOW fee.  AND we invoiced the Neurodiversity session that was delivered, and 100% of the PM fee.  They want to know if we are billing forward, or taking “from the prepayment pot”.  I need to meet with Chuck and SG  to answer this question before Thursday COB.  The complexity of this situation suggests a a live discussion.  Thinking about current and future implications goes beyond what we pay LB. 
  
Cheers~ 
  
Andrea Wicks Bowles 
(She/Her/Hers) 
Senior Consultant 
LCW

This was a confusing one 🙂. According to my investigation 🙂, here are the Group M sessions that got canceled/postponed for Larry that would trigger any payment to him (using the old cancelation policy): 2/13 cancelation for 2/24 session = 11 days notice = 50% of $350 due to Larry — $175 due  2/13 cancelation for 2/28 session = 15 days notice = 25% of $350 due to Larry — $87.50 due 3/5 cancelation for 3/14 session = 8 days notice = 50% of $350 due to Larry — $175 due 3/17 cancelation for 3/21 session = 4 days notice = 75% of $350 due Larry — $262.50 due Total due Larry ( if we use our old cancelation policy language - which was NOT in his PA) is $700. However, I do not know anything about the Spencer Stuart & Aflac programs. Were they cancelled? How much notice was Larry given? @Andrea Wicks Bowles: mailto:a.wicksbowles@lcwmail.com  - Can you please answer this for me? If I’m reading that correctly, then we do not owe Larry anything…unless the rescheduled dates do not work for him. Can you confirm if that’s correct?   Maybe easier to explain on a call. I’ll be back tomorrow if you prefer to chat about it.    Thank you!   On Mar 31, 2025, at 9:31 AM, Rebecca Parrilla wrote: ﻿ We’re not charging GroupM anything because: Their sensitive situation with LCW right now They are going to tell us that the session dates were set in stone, they said ‘probably’ or ‘pending our internal reviews and decision making’ Please see GroupM SOW language below, especially the first bullet. I will be reminding them of the last bullet (in yellow) today when we meet and will also be asking them for a firm launch date. Please see attached for my PA to Larry. I think in my haste to negotiate and note Larry’s requirements about the terms and the two week notice in case he got a job, I just deleted the standard cancellations language and inserted the language you see there.   GroupM SOW 2024-139: 
https://www.dropbox.com/scl/fi/qmn2id2qiyaznpnf4jri3/SOW-2024-139-LEADING-WITH-INCLUSION.pdf?rlkey=uxsc6cvmc45093j52aq44yzjp&dl=0
 Cancelations & Postponements language: Scheduled sessions may be canceled or postponed at any time before scheduled delivery at no cost, providing the session is rescheduled within six months, any non-refundable travel expenses will still be billed Scheduled sessions canceled or postponed within 8-14 days of delivery, if not rescheduled, will incur a charge of 50% of the session cost, plus any non-refundable travel expenses Scheduled sessions canceled or postponed within 3-7 days of delivery, if not rescheduled, will incur a charge of 75% of the session cost, plus any non-refundable travel expenses Scheduled sessions canceled or postponed within 2 days of delivery, if not rescheduled will incur a charge of the full program fee, plus any non-refundable travel expenses Cancellation and postponement charges will be invoiced immediately and may not be applied to future sessions Cancellation & postponement fees are in addition to the original session fees Scheduled sessions postponed more than twice, no matter the notice, will incur a charge of 50% of the session cost, plus any non-refundable travel expenses   One option would be to pay Larry an advance (50%?) for his future GroupM facilitations. I feel confident that the sessions will finally begin on Friday, May 2nd (I will try my best to get them to commit today during our meeting).  We can also guarantee him a certain # of sessions and also pay him a certain fee or pct (15%?) re: the sessions that were postponed. (Btw he emailed me that he wasn’t able to do April 28 after all so that date should be crossed off the list on the SOW and it’s actually a total of 16 GroupM sessions, not 18).I’m not sure there would have been a ton of prep for Larry for these sessions because he’s facilitated this content many times in advance, however, he did reserve the dates so in my opinion some courtesy compensation is warranted for the opportunity cost.  We had contracted to pay him $350 per GroupM session so that would be a total of $840 for 16 sessions.   Here’s the timeline of GroupM events in case helpful: 2/10/25: Emailed Larry first Project Assignment: 
https://www.dropbox.com/scl/fi/cgc6hgzlh1tmho1gtkmxv/PA-25-01_Baker_Feb-Apri2025-Facilitationsv1.pdf?rlkey=8hi9thqdm0xykzgl1kzk1tl4c&dl=0

 with the first session being March 14th 2/19: Received signed PA back from Larry 2/21: Larry asked me about a Spencer Stewart session. I asked Chuck about it, He confirmed that this should be added to the PA so I sent Larry a new PA:

Nicole Begin forwarded message: From: Larry Baker Date: March 31, 2025 at 8:45:40 AM EDT To: Chuck Adams , Nicole Barile Cc: Rebecca Parrilla , Andrea Wicks Bowles Subject: FW: Email ﻿   Hello all,   I am writing to address the series of postponed training sessions with Group M and Aflac during February, March, and April, for which I have not received compensation despite significant preparation time. Detailed Session Breakdown Group M Sessions (9 total) 1.      Topic: Building an Inclusive Environment 2.      Scheduled Dates: 1.      February 24 2.      March 14, 24, 28, 31 3.      April 4, 11, 14, 25 1.      Contracted Rate: $350 per session 2.      Total Potential Earnings: $3,150 Aflac Postponed Sessions 1.      "How Culture Influences Communication Styles" 1.      Scheduled Date: February 26 2.      Session Rate: $300 1.      "Managing Bias in Talent Review" 1.      Scheduled Date: March 6 2.      Session Rate: $500 1.      "Fostering Inclusive Leadership" 1.      Scheduled Date: March 12 2.      Session Rate: $350 1.      Total Potential Aflac Earnings: $1,150 Total Uncompensated Earnings: $4,300 Compensation Proposal While recognizing the unprecedented challenges we are experiencing, I propose a fair resolution based on the following considerations: 1.      Substantial Preparation Time: Significant effort was invested in preparing for these sessions. 2.      SOW Flexibility: Existing contract language supports compensation considerations. 3.      Cancellation Policy Alignment: Proposing compensation at 50% of the original session rate. Proposed Compensation: $2,150 Negotiation Openness I am committed to maintaining a professional and collaborative relationship. I am open to discussing a mutually agreeable compensation arrangement that recognizes the time and expertise invested while supporting our continued business partnership. Next Steps I welcome the opportunity to discuss this matter further and find a resolution that works for both parties. Thank you for your careful consideration.   Disclaimer The information contained in this communication from the sender is confidential. Hi Chuck, 
  
I hope this message finds you well! Jaya and I have been exploring what these LCW sessions could look like for our ERG Leadership team and have a couple question regarding our global colleagues: 
  
We currently have three executive sponsors based in EMEA and one in APAC. We can likely schedule sessions at a fairly reasonable time for our Americas and EMEA colleagues, but unfortunately not APAC. We obviously do not want our APAC colleague to feel excluded, so I am curious to know how you generally handle a timing issue like this? 
Along the same vein, we have several APAC and EMEA colleagues who serve in leadership of the ERGs (as co-leads, not Executive Sponsors), so we run into the scheduling issue again. We do want to be able to accommodate all time zones, so I presume we would need a separate session for our EMEA/APAC colleagues. Would there be an additional cost associated with this, and, if so, what would the costs be? We want to be cost conscious but are mindful of these time zone issues and want to be fair to your team, as well. 
  
Thanks in advance! 
  
Best, 
Liz 
  
Elizabeth “Liz” Bushner
 
(she/her/hers)
Spencer Stuart
 San Francisco
 
T 415.808.8905

The Society of Asian Scientists and Engineers (SASE)
 is hosting their annual Women's Leadership Conference (WLC) designed for Asian-heritage women professionals, and is open to anyone.
 
Our CEO Farah Bala will be speaking on the topic of 
Unlocking Career Growth Through Self Leadership 
on Friday, April 25, 2025.
 
REGISTER HERE - WLC April 25, 2025
FARSIGHT is thrilled to partner with our friends at 
The Serica Initiative
 to create their pilot 
AAPI Women's Mentorship Program
. We love their work and mission to amplify AAPI voices and communities across the globe and it is an honor to support them in this new initiative!
 
If you are an NYC-based, woman AAPI people-leader looking to deepen your leadership and influence through mentor support, and would like to apply, 
Applications open tomorrow, April 2, 2025
 
THE SERICA INITIATIVE
FARSIGHT CHATS
 thanks you for your Support and Listenership
It makes every episode possible!
Please 
Like
,

 and

FARSIGHT
 FRIDAY
 
started in response to the multiple pandemics that have fueled racism and division in the United States and around the world in 2020. This video podcast attempts to dissect topics, new and old, that are current to our times.
 
We hope these episodes give you an 
opportunity to check in, reflect, and process how you are experiencing these times. We learn a lot by being in conversation, and by listening to diverse perspectives. Please continue these conversations with your communities, your families, your teams, your organizations. The more we speak of these topics, the more we normalize their existence and complexity; providing the crucial antidote to erasure and division.

subject: An email was logged on records you're following
body:
An email was logged on records you're following
 
 
Hi, colleagues. Sorry for sending yet another email, but wanted to let you know that after reading 
the actual EEOC document
, it seems to me that Paradigm’s last row below can be confusing or even misleading. Regarding training, the EEOC guidelines state: 
  
Title VII also prohibits employers from limiting, segregating, or classifying employees or applicants based on race, sex, or other protected characteristics in a way that affects their status or deprives them of employment opportunities...
[28]
  
  
Unlawful limiting, segregating, or classifying workers related to DEI can arise when employers separate workers into groups based on race, sex, or another protected characteristic when administering DEI or any trainings, workplace programming, or other privileges of employment, even if the separate groups receive the same programming content or amount of employer resources.
[31]
… 
  
Employers instead should provide “training and mentoring that provides workers 
of all backgrounds
 the opportunity, skill, experience, and information necessary to perform well, and to ascend to upper-level jobs.”
[32]
  
  
So I interpret the above as separating workers in terms of who participates or is given the oppty to attend the training, not the 
content
 of the training. 
  
Just wanted to clarify that. RP 
  
Rebecca M. Parrilla
 
(MBA, Latina, LGBTQ, Mom)
 
(she/her) 
Why pronouns matter
 
Head of Client Solutions 
LCW

71% of respondents said lack of relevance is the key reason why they ignore cold emails, far above any other reason. And 
the average
 
campaign reply rate is 4.1%
. 
At the same time, 6 in 10 decision makers prefer getting emails over LinkedIn DMs or phone calls.
We’ve learned this after analyzing 11 million cold emails and surveying hundreds of decision makers. 
We’ve also examined the impact of using custom attributes, campaign recipient count, free webmail vs. custom domain, and much more.
Read the analysis
 
 
 
We’re down to the Open Rate 8.
Some favorites are out, and a few dark horses are still in the running—vying for a spot in the Follow Up Four.
Who moves on? It’s up to you. Vote and have your say in who wins the Messaging Madness!
Vote here!
 
 
 
2x reply rates with Hunter
Darwinbox is an HR platform, a unicorn valued at over $1B, and an esteemed Hunter customer.
Multiple teams at Darwinbox use Hunter for email finding and verification. After switching from their previous data provider, their average reply rates doubled.
Read more
 
 
 
Myths surrounding cold email, dispelled
Cold email is a viable way to grow almost any business, from a multi-billion dollar enterprise to a local photography studio.
However, persistent misconceptions still make some business leaders shy away from it. We dispel 9 of those myths here.
Read more
 
 
Join your monthly Q&A
Find out what’s ahead at Hunter for Q2, and bring your questions to your live and exclusive Q&A on April 16th.
Join the next session here
 
 
 
Hunter is more than a data provider. We’re here to help you land more replies. That means giving you the right tools for the entire outreach process, including copywriting. 
In the coming months, you’ll see powerful new features designed to help you send relevant, personalized emails effortlessly. Hunter will assist you in crafting sequences that take what you know about each recipient—their needs, their challenges—and turn it into highly engaging messages.

   From: Rocio Alvarez Sent: Thursday, March 20, 2025 5:16 PM To: Chuck Adams Subject: Re: LCW Quotes for Programming Thank you very much, Chuck! I've had some time to go through the menu and have a few questions about pricing for each course. I'm interested in the following sessions, divided by type. Are they priced by the hour, by the session or both? It's a little of both and the number of faciltators. Let's assume we have 40 people in each session, would we need 3 or 4 sessions of each? We usually suggest that sessions be limited to 25-30 people in order to maximize interaction and engagement. We find that active participation suffers as the number of participants increases. We are flexible, though.  Facilitated learning Cultural Competence & Inclusion Skill-Building: Building a Culture of Inclusion (all audiences)  Pricing is $8,000 per session.  Inclusion Skill-Building: Brave Conversations on Race + Power of Allyship Culture (all audiences) Pricing is $8,000 per session for each .  Cultural Competence & Inclusion Skill-Building: Building a Culture of Inclusion Pricing is $12,000  per session + Leading with Conscious Inclusion (managers & leaders)  Pricing is $8,000 per session ELearning - We have two models for elearning; 1) a price based on org size which starts at $20k for up to 10,000 users, and 2) for smaller organizations we host the modules for $50 for each user (for 12 months). The latter would work best for you folks. Foundations of Diversity & Inclusion (all audiences) Fostering Collaboration (all audiences) Mini-workshops Foundations of Diversity & Inclusion Price is $3,600 per session Spotlight on Intersectionality Price is $3,600 per session I realize I am repeating myself with the foundations courses, but I think it's important to offer this in different ways so the message clicks for everyone, and also because I don't know that everyone will attend each kind of session. Can you tell me what the cost of those selections would be, based on a company of 160 people? We have 50-60 people who are people managers and would be in the manager & leader sessions. Thank you! On Mon, Mar 10, 2025 at 2:05 PM Chuck Adams < c.adams@lcwmail.com: mailto:c.adams@lcwmail.com> wrote: Hi, Rocio –   Attached are the information deck and  proposal with pricing we discussed. Don’t be put off by the final cost in the proposal. 😊  To build the proposal I had to assume some things around the final number of sessions and the specific manager/leader training you might be interested in. Note that any of the products in the deck can be swapped out for assumptions made in the proposal.   Either way, think of this as a menu that we can customize accordingly.   You’ll notice that I did not provide pricing on the Diversity Leadership Governance piece yet. I need to talk with the team about how best to represent that outside of the ERG/BRG Consulting Package. As I was reviewing the program I noticed that there wasn’t a clean line item for that piece alone. I will work to get you that tomorrow.   Please let me know if you want to meet and discuss anything sent here. We can schedule a follow up call for end of this week/early next week at your convenience.   Best,   Chuck   Chuck Adams (He/Him) Chief Executive Officer LCW Office: +1.773.938.4285 Mobile: +1.630.373.5068     Website:

Hi Jacquie, 
Wow, you almost broke 100 participants, that is fantastic.  Chuck thought that the session went well.  He and Hanadi enjoy working together.  I hope your colleagues felt it was time well spent.  Any feedback is always appreciated. 
  
The session evaluation data should be ready early next week.  I like to give folks a couple of days to complete the survey, and then send results to you.  To be honest, I am not sure why the transcript function was turned on.  In general, we do not provide a copy of the session transcript.   I hope you will understand.  
  
Perhaps we can touch base next week.  It would be great to know what Della had to say as well.  I will send the survey results, and then you and I can talk about the potential for additional sessions of interest for your organization.     
  
Have a great rest of the week.  It is a pleasure working with you. 
  
Cheers~

Thanks, Nicole. 
  
I’d also replace the second quote under item #1 to make it broader and applicable to different industries. I wrote that quote for GroupM, a media planning organization. So maybe replace with: 
  
“If we make business decisions based on outdated assumptions, we risk missing opportunities and alienating potential customers. When we understand and work to meet the needs of a diverse marketplace, we’ll have stronger customer engagement and better business outcomes." 
  
I also wrote the second quote under item #2 for GroupM. So I’d edit that one to: 
“If our company wants to be the best in the marketplace, we must understand
...” 
  
I agree with Chuck’s suggestion for the example for item #3. I’d recommend using ‘employee’ (or even ‘manager’) instead of ‘worker.’   
  
Re: item #4 and Chuck’s suggestion, I might add a third line as opposed to replacing one of the answers that are already there. I would also slightly edit the language to:  
“Quotas have been illegal for some time. Often people confuse quotas with earnest attempts to include a broader pool of qualified candidates so we can have a better chance of selecting the best people for our open roles.”
 
  
Re: item #5, an example statement could be 
“I don’t know why people make such a big deal about inclusion. People just need to have thicker skin”.
 The quote intentionally brings up where you grew up because it’s meant to generate empathy and understanding from a privileged (non-underrepresented) person. 
  
Re: item #6, I like Chuck’s suggestion and would slightly edit it thusly: 
“Why should we devote time and money to inclusion? We’re a profit-seeking company.” 
  
Re: Chuck’s suggestion about a statement that ties DEI to company values, we could add a second line under item #5 (“Appeal to Fairness & Ethics”) that touches on this. For example: 
“If we want to live out our corporate values of excellence, innovation, and customer commitment, we must create an environment where every employee can contribute their best work.  When we foster an inclusive culture where everyone is engaged and able to contribute fully, we unlock the full potential of our people—our most valuable asset."
 
  
If you provide me with the PPT, I can make all these changes myself and then resend to Keri.
 
  
Rebecca M. Parrilla
 
(MBA, Latina, LGBTQ, Mom)

Dear Team, I hope this email finds you well. My name is Sanjay Ray, a PROZ Certified PRO with 72 WWA endorsements and a proud member of the ATA. I lead a dedicated team of experienced translators specializing in Indian languages, including Urdu, Bengali, Punjabi, Gujarati, and Hindi. We provide a comprehensive range of services, including video translation, transcription, subtitling, voice-over, and document translation. Our expertise ensures accurate and culturally nuanced translations, helping you effectively reach diverse audiences. If you require professional support in any of these languages, I would be delighted to discuss how we can collaborate. Please feel free to save my contact details for future reference: info@indianscripts.com. Thank you for considering Indianscripts for your linguistic needs. subject: Spring into Earth Day
body:
BrainPOP has all you need—from natural resources to pollution
 
View this email in your browser
 
 
 
 
 
 
Spring is bursting with new life, and so is our April newsletter! Get ready to plant the seeds of Earth Day knowledge with this month's lesson ideas and watch your students’ brains grow with ideas. 
 
 
 
 
 
Engage students with topics like… 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Natural Resources 
 
Introduce learners to Earth's resources— from air and minerals to renewable vs nonrenewable—and why conservation matters. 
 
Explore topic
 
 
 
 
 
 
How do visible and invisible sources of pollution affect the environment? 
 
This free investigation lets middle schoolers discover causes and effects of water, air, and light pollution. 
 
Explore Investigation
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Using teaching strategies like… 
 
“Five learning activities, shared by teachers of all subject areas, for how to easily and meaningfully integrate Earth Day activities across the curriculum.” 
 
5 Activities to Celebrate Earth Day
 
 
 
 
 
And read stories about… 
 
 
 
 
 
Why Teachers Who Grew Up on BrainPOP Choose it in Their Classrooms Today
 
 
 
 
 
Try BrainPOP for yourself with 
9 free topics!
 
 
 
 
 
Discover BrainPOP Classroom Solutions and see what’s right for you. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
BrainPOP, All Rights Reserved. 71 W 23rd Street, 17th Floor, New York, NY 10010. 
 
Want to change how you receive our emails? You can 
update your preferences
 or 
unsubscribe
 from our mailing list.

Hey, folks -  
It was great chatting with you two this afternoon. I think you're on the right track in considering how best to support your ERG leaders and the executive sponsors who support/guide them.... especially during these times. Our program has been very well received by our clients and I'm sure would prove an effective tool to help to strengthen your ERGs. 
In the quote, you'll see the trainings, the customizations (estimate), and the handbook. Again, the handbook can be removed if you don't feel that you need to memorialize the best practices for future leaders/sponsors.  
Let me know if you have any questions about any of this and we can discuss options to ensure we can fit within your budget. 
I'll reach out next week to continue the conversation. 
Chuck

From:
 Rocio Alvarez
Sent:
 Thursday, March 20, 2025 5:16 PM
To:
 Chuck Adams
Subject:
 Re: LCW Quotes for Programming 
Thank you very much, Chuck! I've had some time to go through the menu and have a few questions about pricing for each course. 
I'm interested in the following sessions, divided by type. Are they priced by the hour, by the session or both? 
It's a little of both and the number of faciltators.
 Let's assume we have 40 people in each session, would we need 3 or 4 sessions of each? 
We usually suggest that sessions be limited to 25-30 people in order to maximize interaction and engagement. We find that active participation suffers as the number of participants increases. We are flexible, though. 
 
Facilitated learning
Cultural Competence & Inclusion Skill-Building: Building a Culture of Inclusion (all audiences)  
Pricing is $8,000 per session. 
 
Inclusion Skill-Building: Brave Conversations on Race + Power of Allyship Culture (all audiences) 
Pricing is $8,000 
per session for each
 
. 
 
Cultural Competence & Inclusion Skill-Building: Building a Culture of Inclusion 
Pricing is $12,000
 
 per session
 + Leading with Conscious Inclusion (managers & leaders)  
Pricing is $8,000 
per session
 
ELearning -
 We have two models for elearning; 1) a price based on org size which starts at $20k for up to 10,000 users, and 2) for smaller organizations we host the modules for $50 for each user (for 12 months). The latter would work best for you folks.
Foundations of Diversity & Inclusion (all audiences)
Fostering Collaboration (all audiences)
Mini-workshops
Foundations of Diversity & Inclusion
 Price is $3,600
 per session
Spotlight on Intersectionality 
Price is $3,600 per session
I realize I am repeating myself with the foundations courses, but I think it's important to offer this in different ways so the message clicks for everyone, and also because I don't know that everyone will attend each kind of session. 
Can you tell me what the cost of those selections would be, based on a company of 160 people? We have 50-60 people who are people managers and would be in the manager & leader sessions. 
Thank you! 
On Mon, Mar 10, 2025 at 2:05 PM Chuck Adams < 
c.adams@lcwmail.com
> wrote: 
Hi, Rocio –
 
Attached are the information deck and  proposal with pricing we discussed. Don’t be put off by the final cost in the proposal. 
😊
  To build the proposal I had to assume some things around the final number of sessions and the specific manager/leader training you might be interested in. Note that any of the products in the deck can be swapped out for assumptions made in the proposal.
 
Either way, think of this as a menu that we can customize accordingly.
 
You’ll notice that I did not provide pricing on the Diversity Leadership Governance piece yet. I need to talk with the team about how best to represent that outside of the ERG/BRG Consulting Package. As I was reviewing the program I noticed that there wasn’t a clean line item for that piece alone. I will work to get you that tomorrow.
 
Please let me know if you want to meet and discuss anything sent here. We can schedule a follow up call for end of this week/early next week at your convenience.
 
Best,
 
Chuck

Hello Rebecca, 
  
Here is my estimate according to what you provided and all the files, I have divided it by files: 
  
Understanding Your Cultural Lens_FINAL 
Linguistic QA: 7 hs 
Post DTP QA: 2 hs 
LATAM_LeadingInclusively-Solo_2024_FINALv2

Post DTP QA: 3 hs 
  
TOTAL QA TIME
: 24 hs / Language 
TOTAL USD:
 
1800 USD per language
. 
  
  
Linguistic QA: Implies editing translations 
Post DTP QA: involves making sure layout after translation and DTP mirrors exactly as source. 
Both tasks include the revision of everything translated and formatted by client, this includes subtitles of videos. Notes were not included in the estimate. 
These costs also include the implementation of edits in PPT but NOT in videos. If subtitles need to be modified, those costs will be analyzed separately. 
  
Please let me know if this is clear or if the estimate should be provided in any different way.

subject: An email was logged on records you're following
body:
An email was logged on records you're following
 
 
Hi. 
  
Some thoughts (If they are too late in the process we can save them for later): 
  
The second options in questions 1 and 2 are media/advertising/messaging related. While honing your message accurately IS a result of having diverse folks in the decision making process, I think we could mention the higher probability of developing new products and services that appeal to groups outside of a company’s traditional market. 
  
Question 3 needs an example statement. 
How about something like, “I don’t see why we need to spend extra money searching for 
new
 talent. We've been successful hiring a certain type of worker throughout our history.” 
  
The examples in Question 4 indirectly respond to the statement. 
A better response might be, “Hiring quotas have been illegal for some time. What some confuse with quotas are better described as earnest attempts to ensure that underrepresented workers, however that’s defined in your workplace, aren’t underrepresented because of harmful policies and practices.” 
  
Question 5 needs an example statement. 
Not sure that the response resonates as much as it could. Being ignored because of where you grew up seems safe. How might other people know where you grew up? Also, and this is just me, but the only thing divisive about the ‘identity politics’ is that it offends people who don’t have to consider their identity day to day. 
  
Question 6 needs an example statement. 
Something like, “Why is any of this important? We’re a company, not a social nonprofit.” 
  
Apologies if this is late in the game. If we are going to have the EXAMPLE rows present we need to fill them or remove them. There also isn’t an option statement that ties DEI work to company values, which is what I hear from the companies still committed to this work. For some companies this is still a values play. 
  
Chuck Adams
 
(He/Him)
 
Chief Executive Officer 
LCW

Thank you very much, Chuck! I've had some time to go through the menu and have a few questions about pricing for each course. 
I'm interested in the following sessions, divided by type. Are they priced by the hour, by the session or both? Let's assume we have 40 people in each session, would we need 3 or 4 sessions of each? 
Facilitated learning
Cultural Competence & Inclusion Skill-Building: Building a Culture of Inclusion (all audiences)
Inclusion Skill-Building: Brave Conversations on Race + Power of AllyshipCulture (all audiences)
Cultural Competence & Inclusion Skill-Building: Building a Culture of Inclusion + Leading with Conscious Inclusion (managers & leaders) 
eLearning
Foundations of Diversity & Inclusion (all audiences)
Fostering Collaboration (all audiences)
Mini-workshops
Foundations of Diversity & Inclusion
Spotlight on Intersectionality
I realize I am repeating myself with the foundations courses, but I think it's important to offer this in different ways so the message clicks for everyone, and also because I don't know that everyone will attend each kind of session. 
Can you tell me what the cost of those selections would be, based on a company of 160 people? We have 50-60 people who are people managers and would be in the manager & leader sessions. 
Thank you!

In fact, AI is becoming a critical part of long-term marketing strategy according to Canva’s latest report: 
The state of marketing and AI 2025
. 
From instant content generation to smart automation, AI is easing the load so marketers can focus on what matters. Download the report to learn how to double down on impact without burning out.

subject: Design features to fire up your imagination
body:
Try these design features that give you more precision, and more control than ever before.  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ 
Design beyond boundaries.
Get ideas out of your head and into the world with the new release of Adobe Creative Cloud. Innovations in our design apps put the power in your hands.
Explore now
 
 
Fit for print, and more. 
Pesky margins and bleeds are no match for AI‑powered Generative Expand, now in Adobe InDesign. Resize images quickly and easily for a perfect fit.
Discover for yourself
 
Draw it. Trace it. Scale it.
Turn drawings into crisp vectors in Illustrator. Use the fastest, most accurate Image Trace ever to get easy-to-edit results with fewer anchor points.
Learn more

subject: A meeting was logged on records you're following
body:
A meeting was logged on records you're following
 
 
From: Sufi, Amtul Sent: Wednesday, March 19, 2025 6:53:56 PM To: Andrea Wicks Bowles ; Grant, Cindy Cc: Chuck Adams Subject: RE: [External]LCW Resources Hi Andrea, Thank you for providing this.  In follow-up to our discussion, I have listed below the pre-work courses that we would like the team to take in advance of LCW content.  Again, this is live-facilitated content that is facilitated by the Office of DEI.  Based on your review, we would love to know what you are thinking would be good to supplement this content and what the timeline and associated costs may be.  Please let me know if you have any questions, and when would be a good for you to meet in follow-up to discuss further/plan. DEI annual required education, which is online “bite-sized” modules, that cover topics including (In total ~25 min of content): Inclusive Language and Belonging Identifying Microaggressions and Stereotypes Upstander Interventions Expanding your Network How to Intervene with Skill Facing Criticism Microaggressions & Allyship:  90-minute course in which you will learn about micro-aggressions in the workplace and three roles one can have in relation to them: actor, target, and observer. Through the lens of allyship, we will review real clinical examples and explore strategies to intervene and manage after a microaggression. Individual Connection to Bias and Privilege for Leaders:  120-minute course designed for people leaders including managers, supervisors, directors and above, understanding how each of us are impacted by bias and privilege are key components to the personal development we are all called to do if we want to deliver on our ICARE values equitably. Exploring these concepts and how they apply to our leadership skills is a critical first step to leading inclusively. Join this introduction to these concepts to begin your self-reflection journey in DEI as a leader and gain insights into building DEI into your team. Leveraging Privilege for Breakthroughs:  (this has not yet been confirmed to be part of the learning journey):  120-minute course that enables the learner to take a deeper dive into a self-reflective and action-oriented exploration of how we, as leaders, must push through discomfort to create meaningful change within our spheres of influence. Participants in this course will be challenged to identify the behaviors required to truly fulfill the concept of leveraging one’s privilege and ways to foster conversation with their teams. Thank you, Amtul Amtul Sufi (Pronounced Umthul Soofi), MBA Pronouns: She/Her/Hers Director Office of Diversity, Equity and Inclusion Check out the new 2024 DEI Impact Report Ways to get involved! Nominate yourself or a colleague for a cultural/awareness/recognition month employee spotlight. Volunteer to be a storytime reader for a cultural/awareness month. Ways to get involved! Nominate yourself or a colleague for a cultural/awareness/recognition month employee spotlight. Volunteer to be a storytime reader for a cultural/awareness month. 
www.chop.edu
 CHOP’s Commitment to Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion CHOP is committed to building an inclusive culture where employees feel a sense of belonging, connection, and community within their workplace. We are a team dedicated to fostering an environment that allows all to be their authentic selves. We are focused on attracting, cultivating, and retaining diverse talent who can help us deliver on our mission to be a world leader in the advancement of healthcare for children. We strongly encourage all candidates of diverse backgrounds and lived experiences to apply. From: Andrea Wicks Bowles Sent: Friday, March 7, 2025 2:27 PM To: Grant, Cindy ; Sufi, Amtul Cc: Chuck Adams Subject: [External]LCW Resources Hi Cindy and Amtul. It was a pleasure speaking with you yesterday.  Chuck and I look forward to our next conversations. Attached is a document that had been shared with Gilbert.  I wanted to draw your attention to the following: IDI Information and description of the process (3 slides). Building a Culture of Inclusion (for Managers and Leaders) (2 slides). Managing Bias for Managers and Leaders (2 slides). This information will give you a better understanding of what we discussed.  Of course, further clarity is needed, but I thought you might find this material interesting. Have a lovely weekend. Cheers~ Andrea Wicks Bowles (She/Her/Hers) Senior Consultant LCW Website | Twitter | Facebook | LinkedIn View our upcoming events | Sign-up for our newsletter Disclaimer The information contained in this communication from the sender is confidential. It is intended solely for use by the recipient and others authorized to receive it. If you are not the recipient, you are hereby notified that any disclosure, copying, distribution or taking action in relation of the contents of this information is strictly prohibited and may be unlawful. This email has been scanned for viruses and malware, and may have been automatically archived by Mimecast, a leader in email security and cyber resilience. Mimecast integrates email defenses with brand protection, security awareness training, web security, compliance and other essential capabilities. Mimecast helps protect large and small organizations from malicious activity, human error and technology failure; and to lead the movement toward building a more resilient world. To find out more, visit our website. ** This email originated from an EXTERNAL sender to CHOP. Proceed with caution when replying, opening attachments, or clicking links. Do not disclose your CHOP credentials, employee information, or protected health information to a potential hacker**.

   From: Nicole Barile Sent: Thursday, March 13, 2025 12:34 PM To: Rebecca Parrilla ; Andrea Wicks Bowles ; Chuck Adams Subject: April LCW webinar - reply needed - Navigating the Evolving DEI Landscape   Hello friends!   I would like to schedule our April LCW webinar around Navigating the Evolving DEI Landscape.    My thought is that it could be a panel-type discussion with 2 or 3 of us, plus a guest.   The guest I'm thinking about is Howard Ross (of Cook Ross).    And I'm thinking 2 of you might be on it as well (Chuck for sure since you've been having client convos) to 1) share what we're hearing from our clients - how they're adapting to the current climate & 2) offer practical tips for organizations on managing change, facilitating inclusion conversations, etc. I could be a guest as well.   The actual content can be decided on later, but this is the high-level idea.   My thought is to do this after Passover/Easter, so maybe on April 22nd or 23rd around 12pm noon CST.   Please let me know by Wed morning 3/19 if you would be interested and available...and if so, which date works for you. Would could also adjust the time if needed.   Thank you! Nicole   Nicole Barile (She/Her) Chief Operating Officer LCW   Website:

Design with Canva
 
 
 
 
We're counting down to April 10. Got tickets yet? 
 
 
 
Be one of the 4,000+ to experience Canva Create: Uncharted. Witness our biggest product launches ever, 30+ workshops, and even more spaces to upskill, engage, and connect. Plus hear from over a hundred speakers, including some of the most influential in business, tech, and AI, and award-winning creatives like 
Cynthia Erivo, Jon Batiste, Guy Raz, and many more
. 
Don’t miss out! 
Come as a group and save 25% on tickets. Offer ends soon.
 
Save your spot

We haven’t yet scheduled the meet and greet meeting. I sent them some times for this week but they are traveling this week and I haven’t yet sent them time for next week. 
  
They did share a wish list of times for the actual sessions. 
  
AAPI HM Session: Thursday, 5/8, 10-11am PST 
PRIDE Month Session: Tuesday, 6/10, 10-11am PST

The Pride date seems to work with you calendar. I hadn’t confirmed with them yet because I wanted to get your signoff on that first. I will send them some dates for the meet and greet.

subject: New unassigned Email conversation from Pintilei Alexandru
body:
New unassigned Email conversation
 
from: Pintilei Alexandru
 
 
Pintilei Alexandru started 
this conversation
Hello, My name is Alexandru Pintilei (feel free to call me Alex) and I am writing this email hoping that we will work together in the future. I am a *freelance subtitler, translator, captioner, transcriptionist, and template creator *with extensive experience in the field. I am writing to propose a collaboration. My work includes creating English templates (for dubbing as well), subtitling, proofreading, timing and text translation. Over the years, I have worked and still work with clients such as: *TVT, Zoo Digital, iYuno, Amazon, Graffiti Studio, *Sferastudios, *Tvibe, Pixelogic, Plint and many others. *I am open to any tests as well. See my Linkedin profile here: 
https://url.us.m.mimecastprotect.com/s/TWeRCn50A9f7YKxi9frUJly5Q?domain=linkedin.com
 I believe that I can be a valuable asset to your team. I welcome the opportunity to speak with you about how my experience could help your company achieve its goals. Thank you in advance for your consideration. Have a great rest of the week! Alex *Cu stimă,* *Alexandru Pintilei* 0767 222 335

subject: An email was logged on records you're following
body:
An email was logged on records you're following
 
 
Hi, Nicole! 
  
So good to hear from you. Yes. We decided that we could no longer justify a fulltime dedicated facilitator. It was a difficult decision. Larry as been a valuable member of the team and a critical resource for our clients. 
  
We have, however, engaged Larry as a contractor for some ongoing session we have scheduled and look forward to continuing a relationship with him as long as he will have us. 
  
Things here, like in most of the DEI field, are slow but not dead. We are fortunate to enjoy some very long-lasting partnerships with clients that continue to purchase programming and consulting to strengthen inclusion and belonging in their orgs. Many of the others are pausing to review and audit their actions given concerns about Trump’s executive orders. 
  
Most of those companies are still committed to the work but want to make certain they are doing their due diligence regarding legal exposure. 
  
We should connect when you have time. I’d love to hear how things are going at Voya. Let me know if you have time next week. 
  
Thank you for checking in. I appreciate it. 
  
Chuck 
  
  
Chuck Adams

Hi, Rocio – Pardon the delay in getting this to you. I was out ill yesterday. 
  
Attached is the proposal for the ERG Strategy and Governance consulting engagement. You’ll note that the Phase 1 includes two (2) Focus Groups and six (6) 1:1 leader interviews to understand the alignment of expectations of the ERG, what is working and what isn’t, along with suggestions on areas of opportunities. We also like to talk to folks who aren’t part of the ERGs to identify what barriers exist to them joining. The focus groups can be up to 20 people each. Additional focus groups are $4,500. Additional interviews are $1,600. 
  
Let’s plan to connect next week so that I can respond to any questions you might have. 
  
I look forward to talking. 
  
Chuck

subject: New unassigned Email conversation from Ezekiel Christopher
body:
New unassigned Email conversation
 
from: Ezekiel Christopher
 
 
Ezekiel Christopher started 
this conversation
Hi there, I am excited to apply for the *Translator | Linguistic Evaluator* position at your company. With over *six years of experience* in *translation, AI linguistic evaluation, and data annotation*, I bring a unique combination of linguistic expertise and technical proficiency that can be of great value to your organization. In my current role as a *Senior Translator & AI Evaluator at Advent Translation*, I have successfully: - Delivered *high-quality translations* in *German, Russian, and English*, ensuring precision and cultural adaptation. - Conducted *AI response evaluation* and refined datasets for *machine learning models*. - Assisted in *subtitling, transcription, and localization* for multimedia content. Beyond my translation expertise, my proficiency in *CAT tools (SDL Trados, memoQ, Smartcat)* and experience in *legal, medical, and technical translation* enable me to contribute to your team’s success. Additionally, my role in *AI training and linguistic assessments* positions me well to enhance your company’s language services. I am confident that my skill set aligns with your company’s needs, and I would love the opportunity to discuss how I can contribute to your team. I have attached my CV for your review and would be delighted to schedule a conversation at your convenience. Looking forward to your response. Best regards, *Ezekiel Christopher*

body:
An email was logged on records you're following
 
 
Hi, Rocio – 
  
Attached are the information deck and  proposal with pricing we discussed. Don’t be put off by the final cost in the proposal. 
😊
  To build the proposal I had to assume some things around the final number of sessions and the specific manager/leader training you might be interested in. Note that any of the products in the deck can be swapped out for assumptions made in the proposal. 
  
Either way, think of this as a menu that we can customize accordingly. 
  
You’ll notice that I did not provide pricing on the Diversity Leadership Governance piece yet. I need to talk with the team about how best to represent that outside of the ERG/BRG Consulting Package. As I was reviewing the program I noticed that there wasn’t a clean line item for that piece alone. I will work to get you that tomorrow. 
  
Please let me know if you want to meet and discuss anything sent here. We can schedule a follow up call for end of this week/early next week at your convenience. 
  
Best, 
  
Chuck

Design with Canva
 
 
 
 
 
 
Webinar 
 
Canva for sales webinar series
 
 
 
 
March 24-26 2025, 12:00PM EDT • Multiple episodes available
 
 
 
Online
 
 
 
Free
 
Register now
 
 
Hi Pedro,
Join our exclusive three-part webinar series to learn how top sales leaders are transforming their strategies in today’s competitive market.
Unlock expert insights
Hear directly from CROs and sales leaders from companies like Salesforce, Docusign, Salesloft, and eXp Realty, and discover how Canva empowers sales teams to sell visually, collaborate efficiently, and close faster.
Explore all three episodes:
 
1 
 
Episode 1: The state of sales 
Gain insights into the latest B2B sales trends, challenges, and strategies from industry experts. 
 
 
2 
 
Episode 2: ROI roundtable 
Learn how sales and marketing teams are working together to boost efficiency, maximize impact, and drive revenue. 
 
 
3 
 
Episode 3: How Canva uses Canva 
Get an insider look at how Canva’s own sales and success teams use the platform to streamline workflows, engage prospects, and accelerate deal cycles. 
 
Register now and join our three live sessions – plus, get exclusive access to recordings so you never miss an episode.
Let’s sell smarter, close faster, and win more deals together.
Register now
 
  
 
  
Want to join but can’t make it live? 
 
We don’t want you to miss out. Register now and we’ll send you a copy of the recordings after the sessions.

Hello Team,I am a professional translator, copyeditor, and proofreader specializing in both English and Canadian French. With over 20 years of experience, I offer a range of language services, including translation, copyediting, copywriting, and proofreading.Key Highlights: Languages: US English and Canadian French. Domains: Health and Medicine, Life Sciences, Business, Technology, and more. Certifications: Executive Editor of the Journal of Molecular Biomarkers and Diagnosis, with extensive peer-review experience. Tools: SDL Trados Studio, memoQ, Grammarly, and other specialized software for editing and translation.I would appreciate the opportunity to discuss how I can contribute to your team. Design with Canva
 
 
 
 
Unlock workshops, 
activations, and more 
 
 
100+ speakers. 60+ sessions. 30+ hands-on workshops. One day. At Canva Create: Uncharted, you’ll gain real-world skills, fresh insights, new swag, and new connections from across industries. Plus you get to explore more spaces and get exclusive demos from brands you know and love. Don’t miss out on this unforgettable experience. 
Get tickets now 
 
  
 
  
Must-see brand activations
 
Add these to your agenda and get your creative juices flowing.
 
 
Create captivating videos at the LinkedIn Content Studio
 
 
Customize tees, totes, & more with the Star Wars Collection
Learn more
 
  
 
  
Get free demos at the Apps Marketplace, powered by Amazon Web Services
 
Learn tips to simplify your workflow and level up your content at every touchpoint, from your social page to your virtual storefront and beyond.
 
 
Power your productivity apps with Amazon Web Services
 
 
Experience design made simple with Mailchimp
 
 
Bring creativity and organization togethe with Dropbox
 
Simplify design workflow for social campaigns with Meta Design Check
 
 
Unlock endless inspiration from movies, TV, and more
 
 
Streamline workflows by connecting Shopify to Canva
Learn more
 
 
  
Want to keep receiving Canva Create emails?
 
Tell us how you want to continue your journey. You can choose to continue receiving Canva Create 2025 emails or opt-out for now. Don’t worry, you’ll still stay on your other subscriptions when you do this.
Keep them coming

Hiya – 
  
I wanted to confirm your availability for leading a LGBTQ+ Spotlight for GAP in June. They trypically like to select a date in the first couple of weeks of the month but we can suggest a date that works best for you in the span. This is also the group that likes to limit the content to 45 minutes as well. Larry shaved off an activity or two when he did the Black Spotlight. 
  
Let me know and I will schedule a meeting with you and the GAP folks when you return. 
  
Thanks. 
  
Chuck

Hello Language & Culture Worldwide Team, I hope this email finds you well. I am Masahiro Fukuda, interested in the freelance translator position for English to Japanese at your organization. With over 15 years of translation experience and a diverse background in marketing, IT, video games, law, and more, I deliver precise and high-quality translations. Highlights: 450,000+ words translated/proofread. Managed 6.7 million words in editing/proofreading. Specialized in creative translation for travel and hospitality (52,000+ words) and video game localization (46,000+ words). Background: Precise, thorough, and adaptive. Strong communicator and quick learner. Proficient in Trados Studio, Xbench, MateCAT, Memsource, and more. I am eager to contribute to your organization. Please find my resume attached for your consideration. Thank You Masahiro Fukuda

subject: An email was logged on records you're following
body:
An email was logged on records you're following
 
 
Hi, Tisha/Melania – 
  
Attached are the PDFs I wanted you to have for reference as things settle at Envestnet. 
  
You’ll note that I included the handbook cost in the Proposal. You can, of course, decide not to go with the handbook at the end of the day. 
  
Also, for your records, our Mini-Workshops/Spotlights start at $3,600 for a session, depending on facilitation model. We normally suggest that a session be limited to no more than 40 participants. Anything beyond that and the session becomes more lecture than training. Many clients will buy a couple of the session and hold them on different days/times to maximize attendance. 
  
Please let us know if you have any questions. Otherwise, we will check back in with you in a couple of months. 
  
Best, 
  
Chuck

Hi all. Circling back on this mess 🙂. 
In sum, we do not owe Larry anything....technically. 
But, as a goodwill gesture, we will pay him part (about half) of what he is owed. (Note: this amount is different from what Larry is asking for). 
Chuck & I will communicate this all to Larry in the best way we can. 
2 remaining questions: 
@Rebecca Parrilla

Thanks all! Hopefully w won't run into this type of issue again. 
Have the best weekend!
